note.p: Birth: Broad Street, Soho, London, England (18 January 1779)

Career: Worked at the Public Dispensary, London and at St George's Hospital; travelled on the continent as a tutor and was taken prisoner by the French; settled in Manchester (1804); Physician, Manchester Infirmary; went to London (1808); Fullerian Professor, Royal Institution, nominated by John Fuller, the chair's founder; lectured at the Windmill Street School; appointed by the Government to take charge of the inmates of the Millbank Penitentiary (1823); author of a Bridgewater treatise; published his Thesaurus (1852); resigned from Secretaryship of RS (1848); become deaf in old age
Obituaries: Proc Roy Soc 1869-1870 vol 18 pp xxviii-xl
References: Diana E Manuel, 'Marshall Hall, FRS (1790-1857), A Conspectus of His Life and Work' in NR 1980 vol 35 pp 135-166
